tag_narrative: SDG 08: Decent Work and Economic Growth
SDG 16: Peace and Justice Strong Institutions
SDG 17: Partnerships to achieve the Goal
title_narrative: Ensuring Decent Work and Reducing Vulnerabilities for Women and Children in the Context of Labour Migration in Southeast Asia
sector_narrative: Ending violence against women and girls
Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility
description_narrative:
The overall objective of the proposed Action is to protect the rights of women migrant workers and migrant children in Southeast Asia.

Specific objectives: (1) strengthening regional frameworks and national legislation and policies for the protection of the rights of vulnerable groups, especially women and children in the context of labour migration, in line with international standards, (2) improving national and regional prevention and protection mechanisms to reduce violence and rights violations against vulnerable groups, especially women and children in the context of labour migration, including trafficking and smuggling, from a rights-based, gender-sensitive and child-responsive approach, (3) increasing the access of at-risk groups, women migrant workers and children in the context of labour migration, to information, services and collective initiatives to protect themselves from factors related to abuse, exploitation, harassment, violence and trafficking.

result_indicator_description_narrative: Indicator covers number of govt bodies and CSOs implementing strategies for WMW protection in the region.ILO notes: Implementing strategies are understood as programming strategies to protect WMWs rights. The sources of verification can include implementing partnership agreements, TORs, strategy documents, guidelines developed in the course of this project. This can also include technical guidance (eg  NAP inputs) for State Actors (SAs)In addition to CSOs, nonstate actors (NSAs) will also include employers, private recruitment agencies, trade unions.UNW notes:  implementating strategies would be in line with the developed ToR/Scope of work and in the partnership agreement. (SA  state actor; NSA  nonstate actor)

ILO Guidelines Concerning the Measurement of Forced Labour (2018) confirm that a person is classified as being in forced labour if engaged during a specified reference period in any work that is both under the threat of menace of a penalty and involuntary (ILO 2018, para. 5). Threat and menace and involuntary work are also as per ILO Guideline (2018). Malaysia and Thailand will be countries for the collection of the baseline and endline data for this indicator. The sector of work that will be covered is domestic work.

The indicator is an estimate of the number of migrant children engaged in child labour in a receiving country covered by the programme  i.e. child migrants from Cambodia engaged in child labour in Thailand, with the aim to measure potential decrease, thanks to prevention and protection activities under the programme. The proxy indicator uses the available data (i.e. 12.6% out of 500,000  63,000 children).

Indicator covers LM laws, policies, frameworks which have been developed, revised, under implementation.ILO P&B provides: Labour migration frameworks include relevant legislation (laws, rules, and regulations and other measures), policies, action plans and strategies. The scope of these frameworks may govern one or more aspects of labour migration, e.g., fair recruitment, employment, skills development and recognition of qualifications, social protection, occupational safety and health, socioeconomic reintegration, wage protection, or crisis response and/or recovery plans, etc.; and may target specific populations or sectors (pg 84, ILO P&B 20242025, Updated results and measurement frameworks, Jan 2024).The frameworks or mechanisms are considered as adopted when the relevantgovernmental authority formally approves them, in line with the countryspolicymaking process.

Indicator covers those policy and operational recommendations made by the intervention for the protection of migrant women and children which have been accepted by the authorities. Recommendations should be documented.

1.3  of joint actions through bilateral mechanisms for crossborder information sharing, and referral of migrant children to child protection systems. (disaggregated by action type, country, level)Indicator covers number of joint cross border  actions through bilateral mechanisms for crossborder information sharing and referrals.

Indicator covers  of relevant institutions that have implemented new mechanisms/prodcedures for WMW protection through coordinated, multisector services. new mechanisms or procedures refer to innovative strategies, policies, protocols, tools, or approaches designed to enhance the effectiveness of interventions aimed at preventing and responding to violence against women migrant workers. These mechanisms are typically introduced to address existing gaps in services, enhance coordination among stakeholders, leverage technology, or introduce new methodologies for engagement and intervention.Relevant institutions refers to those institutions that are responsible or have a role to play for coordinated, multisector services for VAW, including State actors and nonstate actors.

As prosecution takes signficant time (months and even years), prosecuted cases here means not only cases that have received sentences but also that are in the initial phase (just entered the legal system) or on the process.

ILO Guidelines Concerning the Measurement of Forced Labour (2018) confirm that a person is classified as being in forced labour if engaged during a specified reference period in any work that is both under the threat of menace of a penalty and involuntary (ILO 2018, para. 5). Threat and menace and involuntary work are also as per ILO Guideline (2018). Malaysia and Thailand will be countries for the collection of the baseline and endline data for this indicator. The sector of work that will be covered is domestic work.

The indicator is an estimate of the number of migrant children engaged in child labour in a receiving country covered by the programme  i.e. child migrants from Cambodia engaged in child labour in Thailand, with the aim to measure potential decrease, thanks to prevention and protection activities under the programme. The proxy indicator uses the available data (i.e. 12.6% out of 500,000  63,000 children).

(disaggregated by topic, country) Indicator covers  of reports on data and evidence based information about children in labour migration and migration detention along ThailandCambodia corridor and presented to national/regional bodies.

1.4.2  and type of reports and data related to the issue of children in labour migration along the ThailandCambodia corridor produced by the intervention. (disaggregated by institutions/organisations, country)Indicator covers Number of reports and information material and reports and data on children in labour migration along the ThaiCambodia corridor.

1.4.3  of ASEAN States reporting on the implementation of the ASEAN Regional Action Plan on Protecting the Rights of Children in the Context of Migration with the interventions support. Indicator covers  of AMS reporting on their implementation status of the RPA on CCM for the period 20212025 with technical support from the project.

Indicator covers  of VAW SOPs, protocols, guidelines, codes of conduct which have been codeveloped or strengthened with partners.codeveloped and strengthened CSO or Government partners. This includes but not limited to provision of technical expertise as well as alignment with National and Regional Priorities.

2.1.1      of governments, worker organisations, and employer organisations staff trained who demonstrate good/high knowledge on genderresponsive policies and services for women migrant workers. (disaggregated by target group, sex, country)Indicator covers  of govt, employers and workers organisations (personnel) who have demonstrated good/high scores in trainings.

Indicator covers  of employers organisations and recruitment agencies (organisational level) committed to using the the FR due diligence toolkit.committed refers to employers/RAs who have expressed their intention to apply FR principles in their work as measured in postworkshop surveys.

2.1.3     of state institutions and nonstate actors (CSOs, trade unions, employer organisations) supported by the intervention on, labour migration,  and human rights. GERF 2.23 (disaggregated by country, institution/NSA)Indicator covers  of state institutions and nonstate actors (CSOs, trade unions, employer organisations) (organisational level)  supported by the project. supported includes financial, and technical engagement.

(disaggregated by target group, country) Indicator covers  of institutional personnel and social service providers (personnel) who have demonstrated increased knowledge/skills in trainings and knowledgebuilding activities on VAW survivorcentred approaches.

Indicator covers  of  feedback mechanisms (such as monitoring tools and/or dialogues) that include survivors and advocates, supported by the projectDialogues  refer to learning exchange meetings and/or consultations.

2.3.1  of authorities and service providers staff who successfully completed pre or inservice training curricula on migrant children, including labour issues and alternatives to immigration irregular labour migrants detention. (disaggregated by training type, target group)Indicator covers  of govt and service providers (personnel) who have demonstrated good/high scores in trainings on child migration, labour and detention issues.Indicator 2.3.1 covers only nationallevel staff

Indicator covers  of stakeholders (personnel) who have demonstrated good/high scores in trainings and knowledgebuilding activities on best interests, case management, crossborder protocols for children on the move. 2.3.2 covers only regionallevel capacity building

(disaggregated by sex, age, country)Indicator covers  of participating migrant children/youth involved in the structured engagement

(disaggregated by sex, country)Indicator covers  of justice official who have demonstrated improved knowledge in trainings and knowledgebuilding activities on the principle of nonpunishment

2.4.1     of enforcement and criminal justice authorities staff trained/mentored who show goodhigh knowledge to detect and investigate human trafficking and migrant smuggling using victim and gendersensitive approaches. (disaggregated by target group, topic, sex, country)Indicator covers  of law enforcement and criminal justice stakeholders (personnel) who have demonstrated good/high scores in trainings and knowledgebuilding activities on detecting and investigating trafficking and human smuggling.

2.4.2   Estimated  of youth, migrant women, civil society, human trafficking experts, and allies participating in the host national forums to raise awareness about trafficking in human beings and migrant smuggling and make the online environment safer for at risk populations.(disaggregated by target group, event, country)Indicator covers  target populations and other stakeholders who participate in host national forums. Participation should be supported by implementing agencies and other project stakeholders (e.g. govt, NGOs, etc.)

Indicator covers  of foreign service personnel who have demonstrated good/high scores in trainings and knowledgebuilding activities on victim screening, identification and assistance mechanisms for trafficking and migrant smuggling. Foreign service personnel means officials working in foreign representative office in the countries where this activity is implemented/ or representatives from ministries of foreign affairs of targeted states

Indicator tracks status of functioning of the regional network of  national legal aid service providers, promoted by the project.Functioning means the regional network is established and legal aid is being provided to persons in need.  Promoted by the intervention mean actions are directly attirbuted to the UNODC project activities.

Indicator covers  of AMS countertrafficking units (organisational level) who have demonstrated satisfication with UNODC capacity building activities on victimcentred and gendersensitive coordinated responses to transnational organized crime, including trafficking and smuggling.

2.6.3     of joint investigation teams (JITs) and mutual legal assistance (MLA) accomplished with the interventions support. (disaggregated by countries involved)Indicator covers  of joint investigation teams (JITs) and mutual legal assistance (MLA) accomplished

3.1.2     of grassroots civil society organisations (migrant worker associations) benefitting from EU support. (disaggregated by target group, country) GERF 2.28.Indicator covers  of grassroot  MW associations who have been supported by the project.supported includes both financial and technical support.

3.1.3    of trade unions and migrant workers associations implementing cross border activities to address safe and fair migration, labour exploitation and genderbased discrimination of women migrant workers with the interventions support. (disaggregated by country, target group)Indicator covers  of TUs and  MW associations (organisational level) who implement crossborder activities, with the suppport of the project.Activities can include knowledgeexchanges, casework support, advocacy engagement.

3.2.1    of Migrant Workers Resource Centres (MRCs) that provide counselling, legal aid, information, networking, skills, financial literacy training, referrals among other services to women migrant workers and their families.(disaggregated by country)Indicator covers  of MRCs providing services and info to WMWs and families.

3.2.2    of migrant women provided with information and support services related to safe migration including legal aid, skills development, financial literacy by MRCs and other service providers with the interventions support. (disaggregated by country of destination)Indicator covers  WMWs receiving info and services from MRCs and other service providers.

3.2.3    of employers and training institutions partnering with the intervention that provide migrant women with training and skills development opportunities and recognition of prior learning (disaggregated by work sector, country)Indicator covers  employers and TVETs/training institutions providing trainings (skills and RPL) to WMWs, who are partnering with PROTECT

Indicator covers  of WMWs benefiting from peer networks.Benefitting each year may result in cumulative double counting as benefitting is not the same as joining.Benefitting referes to WMW who are consistently participating in the peer network and may also avail services through the network.

3.4.3  of crossborder cooperation strategies developed with the support of the intervention to disseminate SoPs or share information for case management, through IMS enhancement. (disaggregated by country, work sector)Indicator covers  of crossborder cooperation strategies to disseminate SOPs or information sharing for case management, through IMS enhancement.

Indicator covers  of advocacy interventions undertaken by women migrant networks for safe migration.This would include advocacy through speaking engagements at the meeting/workshop/events that may be organised with Government or CSOs at the regional, national and subnational level. Also include any campaign undertaken as well by UN Women in collaboration with Women Migrant Networks, including but not limited to 16 Days of Activism and International Womens Day.

3.4.1  of service providers who have improved their knowledge and tools to support migrants with their birth registration, legal status and/or nationality and other civil identity documents (disaggregated by country, work sector)Indicator covers  of service providers (personnel) who have improved knowledge and tools to support migrants with birth registration, legal status, nationality and civil identity documentation.

3.4.2  of institutions and organizations that have improved their technical capacity to implement alternatives to detention for migrant children. (disaggregated by country, target group)Indicator covers  of institutions and other organizations (organizational level) who have improved technical capacity to implement detention alternatives for migrant children.

3.4.4.   of women and children who have received information on access to prevention, assistance and protection services targeted for labour migrants with the interventions support. (disaggregated by country, work sector)Indicator covers  of women and children who have received information on access to prevention, assistance and protection services targeted for labour migrants.Women  UNW; children  UNICEF.
